text:
Hi, all! Does anyone have any favorite tools, sites, and other sources for benchmarking compensation? I have, of course, seen the great Superpath Salary Report, but I’m looking for something with more granularity on location, title, and so on.

Thank you so much!

text: did someone say salary? here's some data that might be helpful. <https://superpath.co/blog/content-marketing-salary-report>

attachments.fallback: Your Content Career Headquarters: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters
attachments.text: The average content marketing salary is $93,725. Check out our salary report for more detailed data on job titles, experience and pay discrepancies.
attachments.title: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters

text: Hi Everyone! I'm curious where your content team is placed in relation to the other departments of the company. For example, does the content strategy/content marketing team fall under Ecommerce, Brand, Creative, Product, separate team directly under Marketing? Thanks!

elements.text: Hi Everyone! I'm curious where your content team is placed in relation to the other departments of the company. For example, does the content strategy/content marketing team fall under Ecommerce, Brand, Creative, Product, separate team directly under Marketing? Thanks!

text: I recently moved from under Marketing to under our Creative team within Marketing specifically. My last content role also sat under Creative!

elements.text: I recently moved from under Marketing to under our Creative team within Marketing specifically. My last content role also sat under Creative!

text: I am a content team of one on in an 18-person SaaS startup and I sit on the Growth team. In previous companies I was in, content just fell in “Marketing”

elements.text: I am a content team of one on in an 18-person SaaS startup and I sit on the Growth team. In previous companies I was in, content just fell in “Marketing”

text: Thanks! We're currently under Ecomm (under marketing) but trying to see where it falls elsewhere!

text:
It should depend on what works best for your business. That also might evolve over time. Plus, it can depend on how good a content leader your company can attract and what they might need to drive significant business results.

At NerdWallet, before I joined at early startup stage, I did homework and realized that content could play a major role in growing the business, but whoever led content would need a seat at the exec table. That way, they’d have full access to the business and be able to leverage that visibility while they shaped content as a function.

So even before I applied, I'd decided that I wouldn't join unless I could negotiate a bigger role than they'd advertised.

My pitch worked and I ended up serving on our exec team for my entire 7.5 years and running our content team as an independent function. I reported to the COO and later to the CEO. (Marketing was a separate function, run by someone else. Of course, our teams collaborated and communicated as needed.)

I was recruited away, but I chose my successor, who inherited my seat on NerdWallet’s exec team and still runs content as an independent function. That content team now stands at about 120 FTEs.

At my current employer, we have separate marketing and editorial functions, which roll up to an operating partner who's the equivalent of a CMO. But she defers to me on running the editorial team, because she has no editorial experience. I don't mind reporting to her, because she's amazing.

If you're able to get a highly experienced content leader with a strong track record, that could affect how you organize. Like I was recruited for a head of content role at a public company and they offered to change the reporting structure and level if I'd be willing to take the job, so I wouldn't report to the CMO. If someone with less experience and less potential had taken the job, they would've kept it under the CMO. But they thought if I'd take the role, I could scale a much more significant operation to help build brand and drive the bottom line, possibly break out the content operations as a subsidiary.

That's just an example of the sort of optimizing that might happen, depending on the business and the talent.

Key thing that's important for content folks to recognize: We are at a tipping point with content. More and more companies are seeing them as must-have roles as traditional marketing has lost effectiveness. Increasingly, there are opportunities for strong content leaders to pioneer or reshape roles, to play bigger parts in growing businesses. To do that, they need to increasingly think and operate like business leaders. How you gain such skills can vary, but you'd need them at exec level or C-level. Like some companies are creating chief content officer roles. If they live up to billing, that means those people must perform at C-level, not just be good from a content perspective, but from a business perspective as well.

I highlight this, because sometimes people pattern-match unnecessarily or have self-limiting beliefs. To me, whoever drives strong business value earns more respect, and they can influence org structure and much more. Even if no one's ever done something before, that doesn't mean it's necessarily impossible.
